abstract.p: Carl G Esposito letter, commenting on August 26 article, says Herald Square's above-ground pedestrian congestion problems can be alleviated by refurbishing underground tunnel that once existed between Penn Station and square's subway and PATH train station--two main transportation centers

block.p: Re ''Taking Some of the Chaos Out of Herald Square'' (news article, Aug. 26): Herald Square's congestion problems could be alleviated by refurbishing the underground tunnel that once existed between the two major transportation centers -- Penn Station and the Herald Square subway and PATH train station.

This would reduce above-ground pedestrian congestion in Herald Square and along 32nd and 33rd Streets as well as provide a direct connection for the many people who transfer between these two transportation hubs.

Re ''Taking Some of the Chaos Out of Herald Square'' (news article, Aug. 26): Herald Square's congestion problems could be alleviated by refurbishing the underground tunnel that once existed between the two major transportation centers -- Penn Station and the Herald Square subway and PATH train station.

This would reduce above-ground pedestrian congestion in Herald Square and along 32nd and 33rd Streets as well as provide a direct connection for the many people who transfer between these two transportation hubs.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the city should get together and make this happen. The refurbishment could be financed by underground retail shops, similar to the subterranean malls in Montreal.
CARL G. ESPOSITO Huntington, N.Y., Aug. 27, 2000
